Slideshow
Slideshow Carousels rotate the content to show each of its nested content one at a
time. While a user can still scroll with all available inputs, the Carousel will always snap
and centre to the following or previous frame.
Images retain their natural size but are scaled to fit within a fixed height of the
Carousel.
Behaviours
Carousels are used to place content inside of its content frame. Users can navigate
them by using the scrollbar, slider controls, native scrolling or gestures.
Handle
The position and width of the handle is a representation of the content currently visible
in the content frame, relative to the total width of all content.
The handle is a draggable element on a pointer device, allowing users to pick it up and
move it with their cursor. Clicking or tapping anywhere on the scrollbar track will
attempt to centre the handle on that point, scrolling the contents as it moves to its new
position.
—_—lr
Slider controls
Slider controls will attempt to align the content to the nearest overflow item in the
direction of the control. Slider controls are disabled on touch devices.

\s
Nearest overflow item displayed in pink.
Clicking aligns the nearest overflow item to the opposite edge of the scroll area.
Control alignment is adjusted in small viewports to allow for the touch area to remain inside the page container.
Native scrolling
Carousels allow content scrolling via trackpad, mouse wheel or swiping gestures.
Carousels without overflow
Slider controls and scrollbars are hidden when there is no overflow.
Embrace visual overflow
Revealing overflow provides gives users a useful hint that there's more content for them
to see.
Overflow runs off the edge of the screen on a large breakpoint.
In some cases, revealing overflow interferes with neighboring content. If so, overflow
should be hidden.
Carousel with neighboring fixed elements.
Content length
When possible, avoid making the Carousel too long as this makes it difficult for the user
to scroll through. Try to keep Carousels to five frames or less. The number of frames
can render differently depending on the Carousel's viewport. At minimum, ensure there
is 1 frame in full view.

Ul Carousels are a special, more minimal version of a Carousel that are used to slide
horizontally flowing Ul (e.g. tab bars and pill groups) as opposed to content.
These Carousels use the same Carousel code and logic, but remove features like the
scrollbar and keyboard focusable ‘skip content’ buttons. They also have a different set of
interaction behaviours, as noted below.
Ul Carousels are not a typical component. They're a design pattern that is applied to
groups of Ul elements.
Pointer devices
Overflow controls are always present on pointer devices. A user can navigate the
Carousel by using the slider controls and native scrolling.
